topics.description: Overview of the PCB design process
topics.coverage_text:

But creating these solder traces takes up way too much time.
Or you ogled a new awesome IC that would be perfect for your next project.
But sadly it does only exist as an SMD package, which makes perfboard soldering pretty hard to do.

topics.title: Designing the PCB
topics.description: Creating the outline and connections for the board
topics.coverage_text:
In both cases creating a proper PCB design and ordering it from a PCB manufacturing house is the way to go to save time and play around easily with SMD components.
So in this video I will be showing you step by step what to look out for when creating the schematic of your project
and how we can then turn it easily into a PCB design that we can order through a couple of simple clicks for quite a low price.
Let's get started!
As a practical example for this video I will be using this relatively simple double-sided PCB that I designed.
Which brings me to the first step of this tutorial.
Planning the function of the circuits.
I knew that I wanted to create a microcontroller based circuit.
That reads the position of a joystick and then sends the values through the RF band to receiver.
Also I wanted to power the circuit through a LiPo battery.
Which means I needed a LiPo charge controller IC, a micro USB port to deliver the power for charging.
And a power switch to connect the battery voltage to a 3.3V regulator.
Which converts the unregulated battery voltage into a suitable voltage for the microcontroller.
Last but not least I wanted to monitor the battery voltage through a voltage divider with the microcontroller.
So that when the battery voltage gets close to 3.4V the RF functionality shuts down and the yellow LED lights up.
And with the function of the circuit planned out it was time for step 2.
Which involves searching for suitable components and creating a paper schematic.
For component sourcing I like to use LCSC.
Because their selection is not only big.

topics.title: Wiring the Top Layer
topics.description: Connecting components on the top layer
topics.coverage_text:
But also because we will be ordering the PCBs through JLCPCB later on.
And we can combine that with the LCSC order and thus save shipping costs.
But anyway once I decided on the main ICs.
Which were the ATMEGA328 as a microcontroller.
An NRF24 as the RF transmitter.
A TP4056 as the charge controller.
And a TPS76933dBVR as the voltage regulator.
It was time to think about the packages.
The package basically describes how the IC will physically look like.
And determines whether it is a THT or SMD component.
For example while the NRF24 is only available as a breakout board in THT.
And the TP4056 is only available as an SMD version.
We do have the choice between THT and SMD for the microcontroller.
But since I wanted the circuit to be as small as possible.
I went with the SMD version.
Which I also set as the standard for the remaining complementary components.
Next I planned out on a piece of paper.
How to connect the main ICs to one another.
And also what passive components are necessary to make them all work.
To find that out.
I had a closer look at all the data sheets of the ICs.
And the recommended example circuits.
And if everything fails you can always google your question.
Which should give you a suitable answer in 99% of the cases.
The last thing to do for the paper circuits was to add breakout points.
So that I could later program the microcontroller.
And also hook up the battery and LEDs to the circuits.
Which will be mounted in a separate enclosure.
Now for the passive component selection.
I mainly went with 0603 as the package size.

topics.title: Wiring the Bottom Layer and Vias
topics.description: Creating connections between layers for SMD components
topics.coverage_text:
Which stands for 0.06 by 0.03 inches.
Or 1.6 by 0.8 millimeters.
There also exists a 0402 and a 0201 package.
But I think 0603 is neither too big or too small.
And can still be soldered with an iron with a bit of practice.
And with the component selection and paper schematic being completed.
It was time for step 3.
Creating a proper schematic.
For that I used the EasyEDA free online circuit creator.
After logging in I created a new project.
And there a new schematic.
Then I simply used their online library.
Which also includes pretty much all LCSC components.
To search for my utilized components.
And firstly imported them into the workspace.
But make sure that you choose components.

topics.title: Ground Connections
topics.description: Isolating traces and creating a solid copper ground layer
topics.coverage_text:
With the right package and correct footprint.
Otherwise the PCB design will later not work out.
Once all the main actors of the circuit were imported.
I then used the left aligned resistors with the right package.
And capacitors with the right package.
As the complementary passive components.
And of course we should not forget.
To add male header connectors.
For the breakout points.
Now that we got all of our required components.
In the editor.
We can arrange them to logical blocks.
Which in my case is the power parts.
And the microcontroller parts.
Once that was done.

topics.title: Gerber Files and Ordering the PCB
topics.description: Generating Gerber files and ordering the board from JLC PCB
topics.coverage_text:
I utilized the wire function of the software.
To connect all the components to one another.
According to how I planned it out on paper.
Last but not least.
I then added the ground.
VCC.
And battery voltage supply flags to the schematic.
Which not only completes it.
But also ends the third step of this tutorial.

topics.title: Soldering Tutorial
topics.description: A separate tutorial on soldering components to the PCB
topics.coverage_text:
That means it is time for the last step.
Step 4.
Which is PCB design and ordering.
For that.
We firstly have to click the convert to PCB button.
Which automatically throws all the component footprints.
Into the PCB editor.
Shows how to connect them through the blue lines.
And creates a PCB outline for us.
The first thing I did though.

topics.title: Conclusion
topics.coverage_text:
Was removing the outline.
Because as I mentioned earlier.
I needed a specific PCB size.
For the enclosure.
To do that.
I changed the measuring system to millimeters.
Selected the board outline layer.
And used the track tool.
